I think the real problem is that we are not cancelling the Subscription when we are prematurely completing the write source in WriteStreamSubscriber.
This event is meant to indicate payload end so I don't think we should further override it to mean "last" payload end.

You had a similar discussion with Jo a while ago: #919 (comment)
As was said:

this event is only valuable to determine if we expect any other write on this connection

Taking into account how the read/write is used on H1 server:

we have to suppress this event before it reaches WSS in the case of H1 server

The only thing that was not accounted in this statement is that server may already receive 2+ requests, while graceful closure is triggered. Therefore, pending == 0 is added. Only internal state of RequestResponseCloseHandler knows if there are some requests pending or not.
I'm not sure we need to cancel the Subscription as we want to continue processing until pending == 0.

This is the write method we are discussing (reducing signature for brevity)
Completable write(Publisher)
For this method WriteStreamSubscriber is terminating the Subscriber of the returned Completable but not cancelling the Subscription of the Publisher. So we have a  Subscription which has no way to be cancelled and no more items can be requested. That is the problem why the server does not ever complete as it does not read any more and does not receive any error.
Re: event semantics
I think that statement is overloaded. I do not think the statement was made w.r.t multiple different Publisher (requests) but multiple items from a single Publisher.
With this change would we wait for pending responses to be written if the user adds a Connection: Close header in one of the responses when more requests are pipelined?
I'm agreed that there is also an issue that we do not cancel Subscription in WSS. We will need to fix that one as well in a separate PR, because it's not related to this issue.

As we discussed offline, I've renamed the event to OutboundDataEndEvent.
Also added tests to verify that all use-cases that we discussed in this thread work correctly.
